conclusion: To determine the car's speed at the end of the 2nd second using the provided \( x/t \)-time graph, follow these steps:
The vertical axis represents the position divided by time (\( x/t \)) in meters per second (m/s), which corresponds to velocity. The horizontal axis represents time in seconds (s).
At \( t = 0 \), the value of \( x/t \) is 10 m/s, as marked by the red dot.
The graph is a straight line, indicating a constant velocity.
The general equation of a straight line is \( y = mx + c \). Here, \( y \) is \( x/t \), \( x \) is \( t \), \( m \) is the slope, and \( c \) is the y-intercept.

premise: The line passes through the point (-2, 0) and (0, 10).

conclusion: From the graph, the line crosses the y-axis at 10 m/s, so \( c = 10 \).
The car's speed at \( t = 2 \) seconds is \( \frac{x}{t} = 5(2) + 10 = 20 \text{ m/s} \).
